title: Restaurant Stocks Are Overfed
sub_head: Reopening will be a blessing for U.S. restaurants, but not necessarily for restaurant stock prices
body:
The end of the Covid-19 emergency will be a godsend for the U.S. restaurant industry. But in the near term, it might not be as good for restaurant shareholders as one might expect.
A year after the first coronavirus-fueled market selloff, investors seem to love restaurant stocks as much as Americans love to dine out. And Wall Street has been more than willing to give the industry a pass as Covid-19 and accompanying government restrictions have devastated restaurant traffic and hammered sales.
Brinker International , which owns Chili’s, is up about 90% over the past year, thanks in part to the successful launch of virtual-chicken-wing concept It’s Just Wings. Darden Restaurants , owner of Olive Garden and LongHorn Steakhouse, is up 24% over that same time, while Cheesecake Factory has rallied 42%. All three stocks have at least tripled since the pandemic lows of last March. Meanwhile, business continues to be slow; companies have lately reported comparable sales declines on the order of 12% to 22% from a year earlier.
There was a sound logic for investors to look past the business weakness. Wall Street typically doesn’t give much weight to one-time financial events, and the impact of a global pandemic would seem to be the mother of such one-time situations. Big chains have also been able to access cheap financing to help get through the lean months. A reopening after months of closed dining rooms means there should be significant pent-up demand, at least in theory. That moment could be coming soon: About 45 million Americans have received at least one dose of a vaccine, according to Centers for Disease Control and Prevention data.
Meanwhile, consumers have plenty of cash to spend on an evening out, and fresh stimulus checks could soon be on the way. As a bonus, the need to adapt to a socially distanced business model resulted in better off-premise sales models and other investments that should pay off down the road. Massive industrywide comparable sales growth seems likely in the months ahead.
